explanations.business: The bank that holds the payer's account and initiates the payment instruction on behalf of their customer. This is the financial institution that receives the payment order from the debtor.
explanations.technical: Maps to <DbtrAgt> in pacs.008 and pain.001. Contains the BICFI identifier of the sending financial institution. XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/DbtrAgt/FinInstnId/BICFI
explanations.simple: The bank that sends the money on behalf of the person paying.

explanations.business: The bank that holds the beneficiary's account and will credit the payment to their customer. This is the final destination bank for the payment.
explanations.technical: Maps to <CdtrAgt> in pacs.008 and pain.001. Contains the BICFI of the receiving institution. XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/CdtrAgt/FinInstnId/BICFI
explanations.simple: The bank that receives the money and puts it in the recipient's account.

explanations.business: A bank that acts as an intermediary between the ordering bank and beneficiary bank when they don't have a direct relationship. Correspondent banks facilitate cross-border payments.
explanations.technical: Maps to <IntrmyAgt1>, <IntrmyAgt2>, or <IntrmyAgt3> in pacs.008. Can be multiple intermediaries in a payment chain. XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/IntrmyAgt1/FinInstnId/BICFI
explanations.simple: A middleman bank that helps move money between two banks that don't work directly with each other.

explanations.business: The party (person or company) whose account will be debited to make a payment. The debtor is the originator of the payment instruction.
explanations.technical: Maps to <Dbtr> in pacs.008 and pain.001. Contains name, address, and identification details. XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/Dbtr
explanations.simple: The person or company sending the money (paying the bill).

explanations.business: The party (person or company) whose account will be credited with the payment amount. The creditor is the ultimate recipient of the funds.
explanations.technical: Maps to <Cdtr> in pacs.008 and pain.001. Contains name, address, and identification details. XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/Cdtr
explanations.simple: The person or company receiving the money.

explanations.business: The party that is the original source of funds, when different from the debtor. Used when a party pays on behalf of someone else.
explanations.technical: Maps to <UltmtDbtr> in pacs.008. Optional field used for transparency. XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/UltmtDbtr
explanations.simple: The actual person or company whose money is being sent, if different from who initiated the payment.

explanations.business: The party that will ultimately receive the funds, when different from the creditor. Used when the creditor is collecting on behalf of another party.
explanations.technical: Maps to <UltmtCdtr> in pacs.008. Optional field for payment transparency. XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/UltmtCdtr
explanations.simple: The actual person or company who should ultimately get the money, if different from the account holder.

explanations.business: An 8 or 11-character code that uniquely identifies a financial institution worldwide. Essential for routing international payments to the correct bank.
explanations.technical: Business Identifier Code (formerly Bank Identifier Code). Format: 4 bank code + 2 country + 2 location + 3 branch (optional). Example: DEUTDEFF (Deutsche Bank Frankfurt). Maps to <BICFI> element.
explanations.simple: A unique code like a postal code for banks - tells the system which bank should receive the money.

explanations.business: A standardized international account number format that includes country code, check digits, and domestic account details. Mandatory for SEPA payments and widely used globally.
explanations.technical: International Bank Account Number per ISO 13616. Format: 2 country code + 2 check digits + up to 30 alphanumeric (BBAN). Example: DE89370400440532013000. Maps to <IBAN> element.
explanations.simple: An international version of your bank account number that works across borders.

explanations.business: A globally unique identifier assigned to each payment that allows tracking throughout its lifecycle across all banks in the payment chain. Core component of SWIFT gpi.
explanations.technical: Unique End-to-End Transaction Reference. UUID v4 format (36 characters with hyphens). Example: 97ed4827-7b6f-4491-a06f-b548d5a7512d. Maps to <UETR> in pacs.008.
explanations.simple: A tracking number for your payment - like a package tracking number but for money transfers.

explanations.business: A reference assigned by the debtor/originator that remains unchanged throughout the payment chain. Used by both parties to reconcile payments.
explanations.technical: Maps to <EndToEndId> in pacs.008. Max 35 characters. Must be unique per debtor. Carried from pain.001 through pacs.008 to camt.053/054. XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/PmtId/EndToEndId
explanations.simple: A reference number you choose when sending money that helps both you and the recipient identify the payment.

explanations.business: A reference assigned by the instructing party to identify the payment instruction. Used for internal tracking between direct parties.
explanations.technical: Maps to <InstrId> in pacs.008. Max 35 characters. Unique within message. Can be reassigned by each bank in chain. XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/PmtId/InstrId
explanations.simple: An internal reference number used by banks to track a specific payment instruction.

explanations.business: A unique identifier for the entire message, assigned by the creating party. Used to identify and reference the message in responses or investigations.
explanations.technical: Maps to <MsgId> in GrpHdr of all ISO 20022 messages. Max 35 characters. Must be unique per sender. XPath: GrpHdr/MsgId
explanations.simple: A unique ID for the whole message file, like a document number.

explanations.business: The exact amount requested by the debtor to be transferred to the creditor. This is the amount the sender wants delivered, before any charges are deducted.
explanations.technical: Maps to <InstdAmt> in pacs.008. Includes currency attribute. Should match pain.001 original instruction. XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/Amt/InstdAmt
explanations.simple: The amount of money you asked to send to the recipient.

explanations.business: The amount actually settled between banks. May differ from instructed amount due to currency conversion or when charges are deducted along the payment chain.
explanations.technical: Maps to <IntrBkSttlmAmt> in pacs.008. Mandatory. Includes currency attribute. XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/IntrBkSttlmAmt
explanations.simple: The actual amount that moves between banks, which might be different from what you sent due to fees or currency exchange.

explanations.business: Fees charged by banks for processing the payment. Can be charged to sender (OUR), receiver (BEN), or shared (SHA). Important for understanding the final amount received.
explanations.technical: Maps to <ChrgsInf> in pacs.008 for detailed charges, and <ChrgBr> for charge bearer instruction. XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/ChrgsInf and CdtTrfTxInf/ChrgBr
explanations.simple: The fees that banks charge for sending the payment.

explanations.business: Specifies who pays the transaction fees: debtor pays all (OUR), creditor pays all (BEN), shared between parties (SHA), or following service level (SLEV).
explanations.technical: Maps to <ChrgBr> in pacs.008. Values: DEBT (debtor), CRED (creditor), SHAR (shared), SLEV (service level). XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/ChrgBr
explanations.simple: Who pays the bank fees - the sender, the receiver, or split between them.

explanations.business: The date when the debtor wants the payment to be executed. For immediate payments, this is today. For future-dated payments, this is the scheduled date.
explanations.technical: Maps to <ReqdExctnDt> in pain.001 (customer instruction) or <IntrBkSttlmDt> derived from it. Format: YYYY-MM-DD. XPath: PmtInf/ReqdExctnDt
explanations.simple: The date you want the bank to send the payment.

explanations.business: The date when funds are actually exchanged between banks. This is when the settlement account is debited/credited.
explanations.technical: Maps to <IntrBkSttlmDt> in pacs.008 and pacs.009. Format: YYYY-MM-DD. Must be a valid business day. XPath: CdtTrfTxInf/IntrBkSttlmDt
explanations.simple: The date when the money actually moves between banks.

explanations.business: The date from which interest is calculated on the credited or debited amount. Usually equals the settlement date but can differ.
explanations.technical: Used in camt messages for account statements. Indicates when funds become available for interest calculation. XPath: Ntry/ValDt/Dt
explanations.simple: The date from which your balance starts earning (or owing) interest on the transferred amount.

explanations.business: The exact date and time when the message was created. Used for audit trails and determining message sequence.
explanations.technical: Maps to <CreDtTm> in GrpHdr of all messages. Format: ISO 8601 (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS). XPath: GrpHdr/CreDtTm
explanations.simple: The timestamp showing exactly when the payment message was created.

explanations.business: The process of transmitting, reconciling, and confirming payment instructions between banks before settlement. Ensures all parties agree on the payment details.
explanations.technical: Clearing involves validating messages, checking for duplicate payments, and preparing for settlement. Handled by clearing systems like SWIFT, SEPA CSM, or FedNow.
explanations.simple: The checking process where banks verify and confirm payment details with each other before moving money.

explanations.business: The actual transfer of funds between banks to complete a payment. Settlement is final and irrevocable once completed. Can be real-time (RTGS) or deferred (netting).
explanations.technical: Settlement occurs when central bank accounts or nostro/vostro accounts are debited and credited. Indicated by settlement date and settlement method in messages.
explanations.simple: The moment when money actually moves from one bank to another - the payment is complete.

explanations.business: Consolidating multiple payments between banks into a single net amount to reduce the number of actual fund transfers. Used by clearing houses to improve efficiency.
explanations.technical: Multilateral netting calculates net positions across multiple participants. Settlement only occurs for net amounts. Reduces liquidity requirements.
explanations.simple: Instead of moving money back and forth many times, banks calculate who owes who and only move the difference.

explanations.business: Automated processing of payments without manual intervention. STP reduces errors, speeds up processing, and lowers costs. Key goal of ISO 20022 standardization.
explanations.technical: Achieved through standardized message formats, complete data, and validation rules. STP rate is a key metric for payment systems. Breaks in STP require manual repair.
explanations.simple: When a payment goes through automatically without anyone at the bank needing to look at it or fix anything.

explanations.business: Determining the path a payment takes from sender to receiver, including which correspondent banks and payment systems to use. Good routing optimizes speed and cost.
explanations.technical: Based on BIC codes, clearing system participation, and correspondent relationships. SWIFT's routing tables and bank directory services support routing decisions.
explanations.simple: Figuring out the best path for money to travel from your bank to the recipient's bank.

explanations.business: Payment instruction has been validated and accepted for processing. Initial positive status in the payment lifecycle.
explanations.technical: Transaction Status Code ACCP in pacs.002. Part of External Code Set for Transaction Status. Indicates technical acceptance.
explanations.simple: The bank has received your payment instruction and it looks valid.

explanations.business: Payment instruction has been rejected and will not be processed. Includes a reason code explaining why (e.g., AC04 for closed account).
explanations.technical: Transaction Status Code RJCT in pacs.002. Must include StsRsnInf with reason code. Payment chain stops here. XPath: TxInfAndSts/TxSts
explanations.simple: The payment has been turned down - check the reason code to understand why.

explanations.business: Payment is waiting for further processing. Could be pending validation, awaiting settlement time, or held for compliance review.
explanations.technical: Transaction Status Code PDNG in pacs.002. Intermediate status - payment not yet final. May include pending reason.
explanations.simple: The payment is being processed but hasn't completed yet - it's in a waiting state.

explanations.business: Payment has been accepted and settlement is being processed. The payment is progressing toward completion.
explanations.technical: Transaction Status Code ACSP in pacs.002. Indicates payment accepted at all preceding levels and now processing settlement.
explanations.simple: The payment has been approved and the money is currently being transferred between banks.

explanations.business: Settlement has completed successfully. For SWIFT gpi, this means the payment has reached the beneficiary bank. Final positive status.
explanations.technical: Transaction Status Code ACSC in pacs.002. Final status - settlement irrevocable. In gpi, triggers tracker update.
explanations.simple: Success! The payment has been completed and the money has reached its destination.

explanations.business: Payment has been cancelled before completion. Could be at request of originator or due to timeout/error. Different from rejection.
explanations.technical: Transaction Status Code CANC. Used in camt.056 cancellation requests and responses. May include cancellation reason code.
explanations.simple: The payment was stopped before it completed, either because someone asked to cancel it or something went wrong.

explanations.business: The Single Euro Payments Area - a payment integration initiative covering 36 European countries. Enables cross-border euro payments as easily as domestic ones.
explanations.technical: Governed by European Payments Council (EPC). Uses ISO 20022 messages (pain.001, pacs.008). Includes SCT (credit transfer), SDD (direct debit), and SCT Inst (instant).
explanations.simple: A system that lets people and businesses in Europe send euros to each other as easily as local bank transfers.

aliases: Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication

explanations.business: A global cooperative providing secure messaging services for financial institutions. SWIFT enables cross-border payments worldwide with over 11,000 member institutions.
explanations.technical: Operates the SWIFTNet network. Transitioning from MT messages to MX (ISO 20022). SWIFT gpi provides payment tracking. CBPR+ is their ISO 20022 implementation.
explanations.simple: The main global network that banks use to send payment messages to each other across countries.

explanations.business: SWIFT's implementation of ISO 20022 for cross-border payments. Replaces MT messages with richer, structured MX messages while maintaining global interoperability.
explanations.technical: Usage guidelines for ISO 20022 messages in cross-border context. Defines mandatory/optional fields, code usage, and validation rules. Coexists with MT until full migration.
explanations.simple: SWIFT's new standard for international payments using modern message formats with more detailed information.

explanations.business: The U.S. Federal Reserve's instant payment system launched in 2023. Enables 24/7/365 real-time payments between participating U.S. financial institutions.
explanations.technical: Uses ISO 20022 messaging (pacs.008, pacs.002). Maximum $500,000 per transaction (raised from initial $100,000). Settlement in central bank money.
explanations.simple: America's instant payment system that lets banks send money to each other in seconds, any time of day.

aliases: Trans-European Automated Real-time Gross Settlement Express Transfer

explanations.business: The Eurosystem's RTGS system for high-value euro payments. Used for central bank operations, large-value commercial payments, and settling other payment systems.
explanations.technical: Real-time gross settlement in central bank money. Migrated to TARGET2/T2S consolidated platform. Uses ISO 20022 for interoperability. Settlement finality guaranteed.
explanations.simple: Europe's system for large, important euro payments between banks that need to settle immediately.

explanations.business: The U.S. private-sector real-time payment system for large-value USD payments. Handles 95% of U.S. dollar cross-border payments and 50% of domestic high-value payments.
explanations.technical: Operated by The Clearing House (TCH). Uses netting to optimize liquidity. Settles in Fedwire funds. Processing ISO 20022 migration alongside SWIFT.
explanations.simple: A major U.S. system for big dollar payments, especially international ones coming in and out of America.

explanations.business: A type of payment system where each transaction is settled individually in real-time without netting. Provides immediate finality but requires more liquidity.
explanations.technical: Settlement in central bank money. Each payment processed independently. Examples: Fedwire, TARGET2, CHAPS. Contrast with DNS (Deferred Net Settlement).
explanations.simple: A system where each payment is processed and completed immediately, one at a time, with no delays.

aliases: FI to FI Customer Credit Transfer

explanations.business: The core message for moving funds on behalf of a customer from one bank to another. Contains all payment details including parties, amounts, and remittance information.
explanations.technical: FIToFICstmrCdtTrf - sent between financial institutions. Contains GrpHdr (group header) and CdtTrfTxInf (credit transfer transaction info). Replaces MT103.
explanations.simple: The main message banks use to send money for customers to other banks.

explanations.business: A status message reporting whether a payment has been accepted, rejected, or is pending. Sent in response to payment instructions to confirm processing status.
explanations.technical: FIToFIPmtStsRpt - contains original message reference and status for each transaction. Can report ACCP, RJCT, PDNG, ACSP, ACSC statuses. Replaces MT199/MT299.
explanations.simple: A message telling the sender what happened to their payment - did it go through or was there a problem?

explanations.business: Used to return funds that were previously received via pacs.008. Sent when a payment cannot be applied (e.g., account closed) and the money needs to go back.
explanations.technical: PaymentReturn - contains original transaction reference and return reason code. Links back to original pacs.008 via original references. Replaces MT103 RETN.
explanations.simple: A message for sending money back when a payment can't be completed - like returning a package.

explanations.business: An end-of-day account statement showing all transactions on an account. Provides complete record of debits, credits, and balances for reconciliation.
explanations.technical: BankToCustomerStatement - contains statement with entries, booking/value dates, amounts, and references. Replaces MT940. Part of camt (cash management) family.
explanations.simple: Your daily bank statement as a digital message - shows all money in and out of your account.

explanations.business: A real-time notification when money arrives or leaves your account. Enables immediate awareness of transactions without waiting for end-of-day statements.
explanations.technical: BankToCustomerDebitCreditNotification - provides notification of individual entries. Replaces MT900 (debit) and MT910 (credit). Sent upon booking.
explanations.simple: An instant alert from your bank telling you money just came in or went out of your account.

explanations.business: A message from a corporate customer to their bank requesting one or more payments to be made. The starting point of most credit transfer payment chains.
explanations.technical: CustomerCreditTransferInitiation - sent by debtor to debtor agent. Contains batch of payment instructions. Bank responds with pain.002 status. Triggers pacs.008 creation.
explanations.simple: An order from a company to their bank saying 'please send these payments' - kicks off the payment process.

explanations.business: A request to cancel a payment that has already been sent. Used when a payment was made in error or for fraud investigation. Success depends on payment status.
explanations.technical: FIToFIPaymentCancellationRequest - references original transaction. Requires response via camt.029. Can only succeed if payment not yet final. Part of recall workflow.
explanations.simple: A message asking to stop or reverse a payment that was already sent - like trying to cancel a check.

explanations.business: The global standard for financial messaging developed by ISO. Provides rich, structured data that enables automation, analytics, and interoperability across payment systems.
explanations.technical: XML-based message standard with defined schemas. Organized by business area (pain, pacs, camt, etc.). Replaces MT messages. Maintained by ISO 20022 Registration Authority.
explanations.simple: The modern language banks use to talk to each other about payments - more detailed and standardized than the old way.

explanations.business: The traditional SWIFT message format used for decades. Being replaced by ISO 20022 MX messages but still widely used during the transition period.
explanations.technical: Text-based format with numbered fields. MT1xx (customer payments), MT2xx (FI transfers), MT9xx (statements). Limited to 10,000 characters. Coexistence with MX until full migration.
explanations.simple: The old-style payment messages that banks are gradually replacing with the newer ISO 20022 format.

explanations.business: A financial institution that holds securities on behalf of institutional investors across multiple markets worldwide. Acts as a single point of access to global securities markets.
explanations.technical: Maintains omnibus accounts at local custodians/CSDs. Receives semt.017 statements and consolidates holdings across markets. Examples: State Street, BNY Mellon, Citibank.
explanations.simple: A bank that safeguards your investments in foreign countries by working with local banks in each market.

explanations.business: A bank or institution that holds securities in a specific country or market on behalf of global custodians. Has direct access to the local CSD.
explanations.technical: Maintains accounts at the local CSD. Receives settlement instructions via sese.023 from global custodians and executes locally. Reports holdings via semt.017.
explanations.simple: A local bank in a foreign country that actually holds your stocks in that market.

explanations.business: Infrastructure that holds securities in dematerialized (electronic) form and enables their transfer through book entries. Each major market has one or more CSDs.
explanations.technical: Provides settlement finality for securities transactions. Operates DVP (Delivery vs Payment) settlement. Examples: Euroclear, Clearstream, DTCC, JASDEC.
explanations.simple: The central database that records who owns which stocks and bonds in a country - like the land registry but for securities.

explanations.business: The person or entity that ultimately owns the economic rights to securities, even when held through multiple intermediaries in a custody chain.
explanations.technical: May not appear directly in settlement messages. Rights tracked through custody chain. Relevant for corporate actions (voting, dividends) and regulatory reporting.
explanations.simple: The real owner of stocks or bonds, even though banks might hold them on their behalf.

explanations.business: Settlement mechanism ensuring the simultaneous exchange of securities and cash, so neither party is exposed to settlement risk. If one leg fails, both fail.
explanations.technical: Three models: DvP1 (gross/gross), DvP2 (gross securities/net cash), DvP3 (net/net). Implemented via atomic settlement in CSD systems.
explanations.simple: A safety mechanism where you only give up your money when you receive the stocks, and vice versa - preventing either party from being cheated.

explanations.business: Standard settlement cycle where securities settle two business days after the trade date. Most major markets moved to T+2 to reduce counterparty risk.
explanations.technical: Settlement Date = Trade Date + 2 business days (excluding weekends and market holidays). Maps to <SttlmDt> in sese.023. US moved to T+1 in 2024.
explanations.simple: When you buy stocks, you get them 2 business days later. This gives time for all the paperwork between banks.

explanations.business: Eurosystem's instant payment settlement service enabling 24/7/365 real-time euro payments in central bank money. Payments settle in under 10 seconds.
explanations.technical: Pan-European infrastructure operated by ECB. Uses pacs.008 with SttlmMtd=CLRG. Maximum amount EUR 100,000. Settlement finality in central bank money.
explanations.simple: A European system that lets you send euros instantly, any time of day or night, with the money moving through the central bank.
